intro: Ranunculus asiaticus var. vulgaris, commonly known as the Persian buttercup, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and western Asia. It is characterized by its bright yellow, cup-shaped flowers and trifoliate leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm and thrives in well-drained soil with full sun exposure. It is a member of the Ranunculaceae family and is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens. The flowers bloom in early summer and are pollinated by insects such as bees and butterflies.
